ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I greatly improved my grasp of the Spanish language and learned so much about Latin American cinema in general!
I learned a lot about Latin American films and Latin American history in general.
An overview of famous films in Latin America and history
Vast cultural overview of cinema in Latin America. Good practice speaking Spanish, getting comfortable with the language.
Writing and understanding spanish

I learned so much about Latin American film, culture, and history. I also got to practice my speaking, reading, listening, and writing in Spanish. I think my writing improved the most, followed by listening, speaking, and then reading.
I learned so much about film and watched movies that I never would have watched in the past. It was truly fascinating to learn about something I knew so little about!
This course taught me a lot about the history of  Latin-American cinema. I also learned a lot about the many revolutions and movements that occurred in many Latin-American countries.
This course particularly helped me with my written Spanish skills and provided a great introduction to film studies, as well as the history of some Latin American and Caribbean countries.

I expanded my Spanish vocabulary to include pertinent film terms and also gained insight into the historical influences on Latin American cinema. My ability to critically analyze film was greatly improved by the writing assignments and our discussions of each film.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strength of this course is definitely the movies! It's so great to have the space to explore and discuss culture through cinema.
Sometimes the movies were not very entertaining
The films are very interesting, and the classes are relatively low stakes. Very fun class!
I liked the variety of films

The course is a great introduction to excellent Latin American cinema. The only shame is that there are so many things that we do not get to watch! In the future, more fiction might be nice, but many of the documentaries were really excellent. I can only think of one or two movies that I did not really like in the class, a testament to Prof. Tortora.

Strengths: great variety of films, lots of interesting discussions
Weaknesses: sometimes felt disorganized between the Modules, unclear about what exactly we had to prepare for each class, went over time every class

One of my favorite aspects of this course was getting to talk to a lot of Latin-American filmmakers. Learning about their filmmaking process and about the things they took into consideration we handling the subjects they wanted to talk about was a lot of fun.

Strengths: Films are diverse and great examples of the diversity of Latin America and the Caribbean and their accents, the assigned essays were a good practice of writing skills, student presentations were a good way to practice speaking

Weaknesses: Can be hard to keep up with because there are many assignments

This course does an excellent job of overviewing the breadth of Latin American film available to view, and I appreciated how thorough and diverse the syllabus' offerings were. The assignments were engaging and deepened my understandings of the topics; however, I think spacing out the Canvas forum discussions and the critical essays would make those assignments a bit easier to manage.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Honestly, not much else could be done. I felt like despite Zoom, class was engaging and well organized.

Prof. Tortora ran a very nice class given the virtual circumstances. She also made available other opportunities which were very nice to communicate in Spanish, such as with her friend from Ecuador on Zoom. One thing that was hard was watching video clips of Spanish movies through Zoom. It was already hard for me to understand Spanish, but through the medium of Zoom it became even more difficult to make out the dialogue in the clips that we watched during class (admittedly a very small part of the course).

Getting to talk to film makers hundreds of miles away from the comfort of my dorm room was really amazing. The advent of zoom probably made this a lot more convenient. Lecture felt a little disengaging at times, and it was a little difficult to interaction with classmates.
Recordings of the classes were very helpful for catching anything missed and listening to more Spanish and importantly, your own Spanish.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes for sure! I loved my professor and it was great to watch so many movies and really learn about the evolution of cinema.
Yes! Super interesting look into Latin American film
I definitely would. The professor is the nicest professor ever, and the films we watched were all excellent. The workload was manageable, and practicing Spanish every week was a great time.
Yes, I learned a lot abou culture as well as language

The course is great to improve Spanish skills and learn a lot in the process. I was not particularly confident with the language and now feel much better about it, although I certainly have more to improve. I would guess that I had less exposure to the language than most other students in the class, but I still managed to complete the assignments and do well. It is an excellent course in which you learn a lot and have a great time doing it.
If you are interested in the topic, yes. We talk to a lot of cool filmmakers and watch a lot of great movies. There is a lot of work for the class, though, so you have to be willing to put that in.

If you're interested in learning more about the history of Latin America through the context of film. I'd definitely recommend this course. Your mileage may vary with all the different movies you're assigned to watch, but most of them are very interesting or at the very least have an important message to share.

Absolutely! Be ready to do quite a few assignments but Profesora Tortora's feedback on every assignment is very thorough and helpful. A great introduction to Latin American histories, and film studies too.

I would recommend this course to anyone hoping to get a unique insight into the film industry and its relationship to Latin American culture. Profesora Tortora's expertise is truly invaluable for this course, and the perspectives she brings nin through the guest speakers is not to be missed.
